Award.AwardTitle: Early History of Horned and Duck-billed Dinosaurs: Discoveries in Gansu, China
Award.AbstractNarration:
Early History of Horned and Duck-billed Dinosaurs: Discoveries in
Gansu, China

NSF EAR 1024671

PI Peter Dodson University of Pennsylvania
Co-PI You Hailu Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences, Beijing
Co-PI Li Daqing, Fossil Research and Development Center, Third
Geology and Mineral Resources Exploration Academy, Gansu Provincial Bureau of Geo-exploration and Mineral Development, Lanzhou
Co-PI Xu Xing, Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology,
Beijing
Abstract

Two decades ago China was the third-ranked source of dinosaurs in the world, behind the United States and Mongolia. Since 1996 electrifying discoveries of avian and non-avian dinosaurs from Liaoning, Shandong, Henan, Inner Mongolia, Gansu and Xinjiang have vaulted China to the number one position in the world for dinosaur diversity. China has developed a new cohort of young researchers open to mutually enriching joint scholarship. Gansu Province in northwestern China has proven to be a rich source of abundant and exceptionally well-preserved dinosaur fossils during a critical interval of evolutionary time, the Early Cretaceous. High quality fossils have been described from Gansu only since 1997. In 2009 alone four new genera were described. We propose to sample fossil beds in Gansu that span a wide interval of the Early Cretaceous in order to document exhaustively the critical evolutionary transition from more basal herbivorous dinosaurs to more derived ones. The highly derived hadrosaurid-ceratopsid fauna that dominated Late Cretaceous faunas of the northern hemisphere had its origin during the critical interval of the Early Cretaceous when the archaic Mesozoic pteridosperm-cycadophyte-conifer-dominated flora began to change to the modern angiosperm-dominated flora. Sediments of the late Early Cretaceous Xinminpu Group of northwestern Gansu contain rich faunas of herbivorous dinosaurs. Both the ceratopsians and the ornithopods here are more derived than those of the mid Early Cretaceous Jehol Fauna of Liaoning. The proposed project includes five clear objectives: 1) to discover more horned and duck-billed dinosaurs and to locate specimens within their geological contexts to document their taphonomy. 2) To use stable isotopes of carbon and oxygen to develop a chemostratigraphy of the region and to determine trends in paleoclimate over time. 3) To use Rare Earth Element (REE) analysis to determine the rapidity of burial of fossils as in burrows and to assess trophic structure of the dinosaur communities. 4) To describe in detail the osteology of several key taxa, and to conduct a thorough re-evaluation of the taxonomy of Psittacosauridae, basal Neoceratopsia, and basal Hadrosauria. And 5) To perform the first comprehensive, species-level phylogenetic analyses for (Psittacosauridae + basal Neoceratopsia) and (basal Styracosterna + basal Hadrosauria), incorporating all newly described taxa. The result of the proposed research will be increased knowledge of both new taxa of dinosaurs and the pattern of ascent to dominance of two clades of herbivores within a controlled taphonomic, biogeochemical and biostratigraphic framework.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results in this report are based on field work carried out in 2011, 2012, 2013 and 2015 in Lower Cretaceous sediments of the Gonqpoquan and Yujingzi Basins of the Chinese Gobi Desert in northwestern Gansu Province, and in the Lanzhou-Minhe Basin of southern Gansu Province, Peoples Republic of China. In addition, museum-based research was carried out at the Dalian Museum of Natural History, the Institute for Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing, and the Gansu Geological Museum in Lanzhou, as well as at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. The study focused on the early history of ornithopod and ceratopsian dinosaurs. Ornithopods are two-legged bird-hipped plant-eating dinosaurs and ceratopsians are the horned dinosaurs, also plant-eaters. The basal neoceratopsian Auroraceratops rugosus is very abundant in the Yujingzi Basin and is now represented by more than 80 specimens.  These specimens, which include both complete skulls and skeletons, span a size range from small juvenile to apparent adults, the largest of which is barely a meter long. This little plant-eater stands only half a meter at the hip. It is the subject of an intensive scientific memoir to be published as a monograph of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology in 2017. The ornithopod dinosaurs of the Early Cretaceous of Asia did not achieve the evolutionary level of hadrosaurs, the famous duck-billed dinosaurs of the Late Cretaceous that developed complex batteries of teeth, which numbered in the hundreds in each jaw.  The ornithopods of this region appear to be immediate precursors of hadrosaurs, and thus are called hadrosauroids. We prepared detailed descriptions of two hadrosauroids, one of which is new (Gongpoquansaurus mazongshanensis) and the other of which (Equijubus normani) had been described previously.

Psittacosaurus, the “parrot-beaked reptile,” is one of the most abundant dinosaurs in the world.  Its remains have been found in Lower Cretaceous sediments in Mongolia, China, Russia and possibly Thailand as well.  There is a single report of a psittacosaur from northwestern Gansu, and we did not succeed in finding further specimens, although the search continues.  Psittacosaurus is common in northeastern China (Liaoning), where beds of the Yixian Formation are about 10 million years older (circa 125 million years) than those of the Xinminpu Group of northwestern Gansu, whose beds are dated at about 115 million years. Not only are specimens of Psittacosaurus,   a very primitive ceratopsian, abundant in Liaoning, but they are three-dimensionally preserved although sometimes distorted. We carried out a major study of Psittacosaurus skulls that belonged to three different species: Psittacosaurus lujiatunensis, Psittacosaurus major, and Hongshanosaurus houi. To study these specimens we employed space-age technology, in the form of 3D scanners and geometric morphometrics. We are the first to have used this approach to study dinosaurs skulls. Our results were surprising: we found that skulls attributed to Psittacosaurus lujiatunensis were three-dimensionally preserved in the round and undistorted. Those skulls attributed to Psittacosaurus major were flattened side-to-side, while those skulls attributed to Hongshanosaurus houi preserved with the backs of the skulls sheared forward. We concluded that where three species were named, the latter two represent preservational variants of a single valid species, Psittacosaurus lujiatunensis.   

 It is in the nature of field work that other taxa are found as well.  In the Yujingzi Basin we found several specimens of the large herbivorous theropod Suzhousaurus megatherioides, which evidently was the most-abundant large-bodied plant-eater in the Yujingzi fauna. With its large claws and bulky body it was compared to the Ice Age ground sloth of North America. One of our key recent finds (2015) was a partial skull of a small maniraptoran theropod, a bird-like predator.

We explored the less well-known fauna of the contemporaneous Heckou Group of the Lanzhou-Minhe Basin of southern Gansu. Here no ceratopsians have been found. The only ornithopod so far described is the very large iguanodontian, Lanzhousaurus magnidens, which possesses banana-sized teeth. This fauna appears to be dominated by long-necked sauropods., several of which are of very large size:  Daxiatitan binglingi and Huanghetitan liujiaxiaensis. To this list we added a new sauropod: Yongjinglong datangi. A  very important recent find is a partial specimen of a stegosaur that we a recurrently studying. The specimen demonstrates the unmistakable hallmark of stegosaurs: the teardrop-shaped vertebral body, upswept transverse processes and plates along the back, in this case low and rectangular rather than tall and triangular. Early Cretaceous stegosaurs are extremely rare, and this specimen is unequivocal, and thus very important.

Studies resulting from EAR NSF 1024671 described above are expected to continue for several more years on both sides of the Pacific. Two University of Pennsylvania graduate students have received their Ph.D.s based on this research (EM Morschhauser, Brandon P. Hedrick, Jr.), two other Ph.D. students have worked on aspects of this work (AT McDonald, SA Jasinski) and five undergrads have participated in field work.
